keyTakeAways: The internet's reliance on a small number of cloud providers, such as AWS, creates systemic fragility when one service fails.
The root cause of the outage was a failure in the Domain Name System (DNS), which prevented access to data stored in AWS's DynamoDB and EC2 services.
AWS, despite its scale and reputation, experienced a major service disruption, underscoring that even large tech firms are vulnerable to technical faults.

Historical outages—such as the 2024 CrowdStrike bug and 2024 AT&T network failures—demonstrate that such events are not isolated and highlight recurring vulnerabilities in global digital infrastructure.
The outage resulted in widespread inaccessibility of services including banking, social media, airline booking, and e-commerce, impacting millions globally.
Experts warn that the internet's original design for decentralization and resilience has been compromised by centralization of cloud services.
AWS recommends clearing caches to restore service, showing the need for proactive recovery strategies in digital ecosystems.

namedEntities.name: Amazon Web Services (AWS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A cloud computing platform that hosts critical online services such as banking, social media, e-commerce, and airline booking.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: AWS went down for several hours, causing widespread disruption to numerous major websites and apps, making it central to the article's focus on internet fragility.

namedEntities.name: Domain Name System (DNS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A system that converts user-friendly web addresses (like amazon.com) into IP addresses, enabling internet navigation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A DNS failure caused the outage, preventing access to data stored in AWS databases and disrupting the ability of services to communicate with their data sources.

namedEntities.name: DynamoDB
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A database service offered by AWS that stores customer and user data for various companies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Customers were unable to access data stored in DynamoDB due to the DNS failure, illustrating how core data services are interdependent with infrastructure health.

namedEntities.name: EC2
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A virtual server service used by companies to build and run online applications.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The outage affected EC2 services, demonstrating how a failure in AWS infrastructure impacts a broad range of business operations and applications.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The 2024 CrowdStrike glitch serves as a historical precedent for how a software error can lead to global internet disruptions, reinforcing the theme of systemic fragility.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: AT&T’s past outages are cited as examples of how infrastructure failures in key service providers can disrupt digital economies and gig worker operations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Amazon Web Services (AWS) suffered a significant global outage on Monday, October 20, 2025, lasting several hours and disrupting critical online services such as banking, social media, airline booking, and e-commerce. The root cause was a failure in the Domain Name System (DNS), which prevented access to data stored in AWS’s DynamoDB and EC2 services. Experts note that the internet’s increasing reliance on a small number of cloud providers—despite being originally designed to be resilient and decentralized—creates systemic fragility. This outage echoes earlier events, such as the 2024 CrowdStrike software glitch and AT&T’s network failures, highlighting recurring vulnerabilities in global digital infrastructure. While AWS has not frequently experienced such disruptions, the scale of impact underscores a critical need for redundancy, better failover systems, and more competitive cloud alternatives to prevent cascading failures.
title: The internet just had another global outage. Why does this keep happening?
